text: we are delighted to welcome you this
morning we are definitely having an
opportunity to practice all kinds of
techniques and in flexibility and
innovation and patience and even with
the unpredictability of the weather we
still have a wonderful gathering of
incredible thinkers and doers in this
room and we know that we're going to
have a delightful experience over the
next two days so thank you for
everything that you did to get from
wherever you were 24 hours ago into this
room today which we know involved Planes
Trains automobiles
you know buses taxis for canceled
shuttles all of that thank you so we're
going to start with our formal welcome
we do have a couple of modifications in
the program today and I'll share that
with you so you have a sense of what our
agenda will be but first Robin and David
will offer some opening words thank you
thank you so
so it is really a pleasure for me yet
again to be standing here in front of
this gathering of people for the gender
and work research symposium and and I I
really wanted Laura to do the initial
hello
because really although David's and my
names are always tacked on to the the
people who have organized this really
we've been very much in a support I hope
have been supportive but Laura has
really taken the reins and and and
really taken care of everything and part
of that is because I've been on
sabbatical this year so I wanted to say
a little bit about the history of this
gathering some of you have been to every
one of the symposia that we've had
starting in 2013 the the idea was very
similar actually to this year we we we
had this research symposium to be part
of the celebration of 50 years since the
admission of women to the two-year MBA
program at HBS and some of you may
remember that when we referred to that
whole year of activities as the w50 and
so this was before we had a gender
initiative but I was in a role where the
Dean had asked me to head up those those
activities together with two other
colleagues Boris grace Berg and Cynthia
Montgomery and so one of the things that
we decided to do is to have this
research symposium a space that was
really for scholars to share knowledge
but with also space for practitioners
and so we've always had tried to get
about a hundred hundred and twenty
people in the room with about 20 to 25
percent practitioners which seems like a
really good you know thoughtful
practitioners people who really want to
learn from scholars and scholars who
really want to learn from practitioners
so that's been a theme that I think
carries through as well to this year so
that first year it
was kind of just greatest-hits we Amy
Cuddy and I got together it was like who
is doing interesting research on race
and gender and who's a good speaker so
we had a really very wonderful event and
then we started the gender initiative
shortly after that so we said okay let's
just make this an annual thing and we'll
put it under the you know the auspices
of the gender initiative so I want to
just name give you some of the titles of
the past events and to kind of give a a
bit of a frame around what we're doing
here today so and I have to say over the
years I love to hear that people refer
to this conference as an edgy one so I
think that's just a great adjective I
love it
and I think we are definitely continuing
in that vein as I look at what the
agenda is for for our time together
today
so after greatest hits we had in 2014 we
had relationships among women bridging
racial generational and global divides
2015 was researched to change the world
translating ideas transforming practice
2016 was talking the walk possibilities
for change through dialogue expression
and narrative and last year was
identities images and the spaces in
between so this year is race work and
leadership learning about and from black
leaders black leadership I think so I so
i thing all the way across is always
about the connection between research
and practice so hoping very much to
continue in that vein and we've always
taken an intersectional approach in the
gender initiative so we call it the
gender initiative and when I first
raised this idea to the Dean one
question was well are we gonna then have
to have a race initiative and then what
about an initiative for you know for
LGBTQ and you know I said no this is the
gender initiative it's where I think the
energy in the world
old is right now and this was a few
years ago I think that people will
recognize why we would have a gender
initiative and gender is just a portal
into all of the axes of inequality that
on their own and in interaction with
each other and with gender really shape
the lives and livelihoods and of people
and also our workplaces and so it's
really you know in that spirit that I
very much wanted to invite the the
coordinators the the people in charge of
the ASA 50 festivities which has been
located into what we call the leadership
initiative so that's another initiative
at the school
mm-hmm that Tony Mayo who will be
speaking a little bit later is Co runs
along with Linda hill and and so I said
you know let's let's take the you know
the the infrastructure we already have
in the gender initiative and turn the
topic over to the celebration and the
commemoration of 50 years since the
start of the African American Student
Union we actually think I think we don't
know or do we now know when the first
black student 1915 okay interesting and
also it's also interesting that when we
were looking at the W 50 there was a
there was a program that was run over at
Radcliffe before there was actually
women in the two-year MBA program here
and it was a certificate program for
women and faculty here good hearted
faculty would go over to cross the river
and teach those women at Radcliffe and
we know that there were some black women
who graduated from that program so so I
think we've we've had you know
african-americans in our midst for a
very long time
and I'm just really thrilled that we are
here to to really delve into that
experience and see what we can all learn
from it so I'm going to turn over to
David and
[Laughter]
now first of all it's great to great to
be here as as some of you know I
recently took the position to be the
president of Morehouse College so it
feels like you know I'm throwing a party
for myself today only from the from the
from the vantage point that when I think
about how few people we could have
gotten in this room thirty almost thirty
years ago when I joined the faculty of
the Harvard Business School and to see
the great work that's represented by all
of the people here both in practice as
well as in research is just kind of
overwhelming what I was supposed to do
was to make the connection that Robin
made about the way this came about and
it came about because about two years
ago a group of people here at the
Harvard Business School started to have
a conversation about how do we celebrate
the 50th anniversary of the African
American the formation of the African
American Student Union and there's a
conference that has happened here for I
don't know how many years that's now
named after H Naylor Fitzhugh who was
one of the most well known African
American graduates of the Harvard
Business School and that conference is
mostly for our alumni prospective
students and we started to talk about
how to celebrate that and out of that
came a discussion about well what about
research
and because of the work that Robin had
been doing here with the gender
initiative which as she described has
always been about intersectionality it
was kind of a question of figure and
ground so let's have a research
conference or symposium that makes race
and in particular the black experience
figure rather than ground another thing
that I would that I'm aware of
because of my new role is how this year
really marks a historical moment it's
the 50th anniversary of the African
American Student Union it's also the
50th anniversary of the assassination of
dr. King so if you imagine what the
world was like 50 years ago the cauldron
or crucible of change that it was that's
what we are sort of in my view we're
we're part of that lineage in this very
moment we're marking a historical moment
and just like back then those I think in
I think when they formed Tony's our
resident historian on this there were
five african-americans on campus at the
time there were six but what okay so
there were six African Americans or at
least six six known or self-identified
African Americans on this campus 50
years ago as MBA students they couldn't
imagine what would follow that we'd be
here today in the same way that my guess
is many of us couldn't imagine the world
that would follow dr. King both in terms
of its progress as well as how much more
work there is to do so for me that's
what we're marking with my party that
you guys are having for me
so with that I'll turn it over to Laura
who kick us off
